Did you know that errors on your tax return can mean it will take longer for the IRS to process it? Which in turn, could delay your refund. The IRS wants to remind you that you can avoid many common tax filing errors by using a tax pro, filing electronically or by using IRS Free File. Filing electronically is the most accurate way to file a tax return. To learn about common tax filing errors and how to avoid them, click here: https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/extension-filers-should-avoid-these-errors-when-filing-their-tax-return

IRS
Under the CARES Act, businesses are encouraged to keep employees on their payroll with the Employee Retention Credit. It also helps to make sure workers aren't forced to choose between their paychecks and the public health measures needed to combat the coronavirus. Eligible employers can claim this credit for wages paid after March 12, 2020, and before January 1, 2021.

To learn more about this valuable credit, click here: https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/new-employee-retention-credit-helps-employers-keep-employees-on-payroll

IRS
The IRS urges taxpayers to be on the lookout for scam artists trying to use the Economic Impact Payments as cover for schemes to steal personal information and money. Remember, the IRS will not call, text you, email you or contact you on social media asking for personal or bank account information – even related to the Economic Impact Payments. Also, watch out for emails with attachments or links claiming to have special information about Economic Impact Payments or refunds.
To learn more, click here: https://go.usa.gov/xvrf7

An IRS reminder to retirees: If you have an IRA, you are 70½ or older, and have not yet taken your Retirement Minimum Distribution for 2019, you’re still required to take those distributions by April 1, 2020. IRS
Did you know that the IRS has a tax counseling for the elderly (TCE) program? Not only is it free, but there are sites right in your neighborhood. Keep this in mind when looking for a TCE site: the majority of them are operated by the AARP Foundation’s Tax Aide program. To locate the nearest TCE site use the AARP Site Locator Tool. To learn more, click here: www.irs.gov/tce

The IRS wants to reach as many people as possible, which is why we have tax information available in multiple languages. To get information in one of these languages, click on the language dropdown tab at the top of every IRS.gov page. The dropdown displays the current language translation options available. IRS.gov pages translated into one or more languages also have links to available translations on the right side of the page, just below the title. Languages currently available include Spanish, Chinese, Korean, Russian, Vietnamese and Haitian-Creole. To learn more, click here: https://go.usa.gov/xw4kQ

IRS
If you’re trying to reach the IRS and don’t want to wait long on the phone, check the IRS.gov site for fast access to easy resources:

To find IRS tax forms, visit: www.irs.gov/forms

To file your return for free, visit: www.irs.gov/freefile

For payment options: www.irs.gov/payments

To check the status of your refund, click: www.irs.gov/refunds

For general help, see: www.irs.gov/help

To get answers to your tax questions, like whether you qualify to claim certain credits and deductions, visit: www.irs.gov/ita

IRS
If you receive VA benefits, don’t normally file taxes and have a child, register by May 5 with the IRS Non-Filers’ tool to get an extra $500 in your Economic Impact Payment. Don’t miss the deadline, click here: www.irs.gov/nonfilereip #COVIDreliefIRS - Share this ‘Plus $500 Push’

IRS tip to business owners: As part of the IRS response to the coronavirus pandemic, there’s an employer credit available to businesses that pay family leave to employees. For example, consider it if your employees are unable to work because they’re caring for a child whose school or daycare is closed due to coronavirus. If you would like to learn more about this credit, click here: https://www.irs.gov/coronavirus/coronavirus-tax-relief-for-businesses-and-tax-exempt-entities

Did you request a direct deposit of Economic Impact Payment but the IRS is mailing it?
There are several reasons why your payment may have been sent by mail. These include:
•The payment was already in process before the bank information was entered.
•The IRS does not have the correct bank account information.
•The bank rejected the direct deposit.

The IRS will mail the payment to the address on file. It will typically take up to 14 days for you to receive it. To look at the EIP FAQs, click here: https://www.irs.gov/eipfaq

Under the Families First Coronavirus Response Act, employers can grant paid leave for an employee to take care of their health needs related to COVID-19 or to care for their family members. This relief helps ensure employees are not forced to choose between being paid or staying home to care for themselves, a child or other family member. IRS
Business owner: Have you heard about the Employee Retention Credit? This refundable tax credit is part of the IRS response to the coronavirus pandemic. It is equal to 50% of up to $10,000 in qualified wages an eligible employer pays to employees after March 12, 2020, and before January 1, 2021. You can get immediate access to the credit by reducing the employment tax deposits you are otherwise required to make. To see if you are eligible to claim this IRS tax credit, click here: https://www.irs.gov/coronavirus/employee-retention-credit

#COVIDreliefIRS
